Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2010 10:01PM somersher wrote: I have been in almost your exact situation.  I had two lumpectomies that did not yield clear margins, so on 3/4 I had bilateral mastectomies with tissue expander placement.  The path report from the first lumpectomy showed 2 of 3 nodes had micromets, but my Oncotype score came back a 5.  My surgeon, who is a nationally known breast surgical oncologist who trained at MD Anderson in Houston, says there is no need to treat micromets with chemo (only tamoxifen, as I am ER/PR + and HER- like you) and furthermore did not remove the axillary nodes, as he says a brand new study shows no benefit.  I was happy to be saved from the possible lymphedema.  He said the 5 Oncotype cinched that I would NOT benefit at all from chemo; a medical oncologist at my local state university totally agreed with him.  So I am at peace and feel confident with their recommendation.  I think other docs who are not as up-to-date on the newest literature would still recommend chemo (I know this for a fact; I am married to a surgeon), but I am going with the advice of these pros.  As one pointed out, this does NOT guarantee that I won't have a recurrence - just that doing chemo now would not prevent one.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 07:00AM somersher wrote: I have just gone through this very thing.  I was adamant that I wasn't losing either of my breasts, but after two lumpectomies failed to yield clear margins I had to face the reality that the bad one had to go.  Suddenly it seemed right for me for both of them to go, as this repeatedly facing bad path reports was getting to me.  At my one week post-op visit last week, my surgeon told me that the "good" breast which we removed indeed showed a pre-cancerous situation that was not detected via mammogram or MRI.  So in my case the bilateral proved to be the right decision from the get-go, but even if the pathology had been normal I would not have regretted the decision.  I did immediate reconstruction and will hopefully match when all is said and done.  These are difficult and crummy decisions we have to make; go with what feels right in your gut.  In my case, I switched from one extreme feeling to another in a matter of 3 months, and am at peace with what I chose.  My stats:  ILC, 1.8 cm, ER/PR +, HER2/neu -, 2 of 3 nodes had micromets but they were not removed and I am not doing chemo or rad.
